Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Individual Variation in Dispersal Through a Social Landscape: Causes and Consequences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Young animals must often leave their birthplace and search for a new home before producing their own offspring; such movement between natal and breeding locations is known as natal dispersal. Dispersal behavior underlies many ecological processes. For example, individual movement across the landscape during dispersal provides crucial ecological connectivity in natural populations. However, extraordinarily little is known about how young animals navigate the complex social and ecological environments they encounter during dispersal. This project will use the brush mouse (Peromyscus boylii) as a model system to answer the following questions: 1) How do pre-existing behavioral differences among individuals influence dispersal movements? 2) How do social interactions with resident adults affect the behavior of juveniles as they move through the landscape? 3) How are survival and reproductive success affected by the interplay of socioecological conditions and individual dispersal strategies? This project will utilize a new automated animal tracking system, social network approaches, and genetic tools to develop a more complete understanding of dispersal dynamics in a natural population of brush mice.

This project includes multiple opportunities for training and outreach. Through a multi-institution undergraduate course, students will collaborate across campuses using a wilderness wireless network and social media to coordinate field research projects, collect data, and communicate their experiences to a wider audience. Outreach activities introducing elementary school students to the tracking technology employed in the field research will be developed and distributed. Education and outreach activities will be integrated online: a research blog written by project participants will document the movements of radiotracked animals, social networking sites will allow course participants to communicate their experiences from the field, and outreach activities based on field research methods and data will be made freely available online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research objective of this project was to determine the effects of variation in the social and ecological environments on dispersal behavior by brush mice (Peromyscus boylii). These mice exhibit a great deal of behavioral variation among individuals, and live in an environment that is highly changeable in both time and space. The research team used a combination of behavioral phenotyping, molecular genetic analysis of relatedness, and radio-tracking using an automated telemetry system to investigate these questions. We found that population density did not affect dispersal distance (Mabry 2014). However, mice did respond to spatial variation in population density when choosing where to settle, with mice moving from areas of low population density to areas that supported larger numbers of mice (Wojan et al. 2015). These results suggest that in addition to quantifying dispersal distance, it is important to consider the environment in the areas that animals are moving to and from in studies of dispersal. We also reviewed the literature on personality-dependent dispersal in dynamic social environments (Wey et al. 2015); this paper was published in a special issue of the journal Current Zoology that focused on personality-dependent dispersal, and was co-edited by the postdoctoral researcher (Wey) and principal investigator (Mabry) on this project. We also completed two comparative studies of the interplay of social behavior, behavioral syndromes, and dispersal. Wey et al. (2017) found that mating system, particularly whether a species was socially monogamous, was a better predictor of behavioral variation across species than was body size or pace-of-life. Finally, in a phylogenetic analysis, we determined the evolutionary relationship between mating system and sex-biased dispersal; researchers have long assumed that mating system predicts the existence and direction of sex-biased dispersal in vertebrate animals. However, we found that mating system had no relationship with sex-biased dispersal across mammals or birds (Mabry et al. 2013). Additional projects are currently underway with data collected during the course of this award.

The project also provided several opportunities for education and outreach. The project supported an experiential field ecology course in which a group of New Mexico State University students traveled to the research site to learn about both traditional field techniques and modern methods of animal tracking, then completed independent research projects. In collaboration with the Asombro Institute for Science Education, a non-profit environmental education organization, we developed and offered a program on radio-tracking for K-12 students. This program allows students to use the same technology used in the research to track toy animals in their schoolyards, and has reached over 2,500 students to date. An undergraduate student is currently using her summer research experiences with this project to inform the development of an educational module for junior high school students that will use freely-available online animal movement data to teach concepts in biology and mathematics.

Eighteen undergraduate students gained research experience through this project; 13 of the students are female and several are members of groups that are underrepresented in science. Five graduate students have participated in this research, and have produced 1 Ph.D. dissertation and 2 M.S. theses to date. One postdoctoral researcher gained research experience, and two postdocs gained teaching experience through the field ecology class. In addition to 5 published papers and 3 Ph.D./M.S. theses, this project has resulted in 18 presentations at universities and national/international scientific meetings.
